Universität Regensburg - Evolution, Verhalten und Genetik Universität Regensburg > Fakultäten > Biologie und Vkl > Einrichtungen > Zoologie > LS Heinze > Staff > Sylvia Cremer Links Staff Research Teaching Publications Dr. Sylvia Cremer Research Associate Evolution, Behaviour & Genetics Biology I University of Regensburg D-93040 Regensburg Germany +49 941 943 3001 sylvia.cremer(at)biologie.uni-regensburg.de CV Publications Previous Research: Postdoc University of Copenhagen Wissenschaftskolleg zu Berlin Lebendimpfstoff auf sechs Beinen Disease & Immunity (Seminar) Research Interest Living in social groups has many benefits, but also increases disease transmission rates between individuals. To counteract this risk, social insects have evolved collective disease defence strategies. These Social Immune Systems result from the co-operation of the individual group members to combat infection of the colony. They comprise behavioural, physiological and organisational adaptations of the colony. Study Questions What are the costs and benefits of social immunity for individual group members? How are collective defences organised between group members? How do ants recognise parasites and diseased group members? Universität Regensburg - Evolution, Verhalten und Genetik Universität Regensburg > Fakultäten > Biologie und Vkl > Einrichtungen > Zoologie > LS Heinze > Staff > Temim Deli Links Staff Research Teaching Publications Mr. Temim Deli Laboratory of Evolution, Behavior and Genetics Biology I University of Regensburg D-93040 Regensburg Germany E-Mail: Temim.Deli@biologie.uni-regensburg.de Curruculum vitae 1999: Baccalaureate in experimental Sciences, Secondary School Okba ibn Nafeh, Kairouan. Tunisia. 2004: ?Maitrise? in Biological Sciences, Higher Institue of Biotechnology, Monastir. Tunisia. 2006: Master in Genetics and Aquatic Biodiversity, Higher Institute of Biotechnology, Monastir. Tunisia. PhD Thesis Project: Phylogeography and population genetic structure of two coastal crab species Carcinus aestuarii and Pachygrapsus marmoratus in the Mediterranean Sea. Background and targets: In the frame of my PhD thesis, I am focusing on comparative phylogeography and population genetic structure of two coastal crab species: the green crab Carcinus aestuarii (Figure 1) and the marbled crab Pachygrapsus marmoratus (Figure 2)in the Mediterranean Sea. These are two of the most common crab species from the Mediterranean coastline and play an important role in structuring the marine intertidal community. They occur in habitats with different wave exposure, have different dispersal strategies, and can cope with different environmental conditions. Recent investigations separately carried out on these species along the European coasts showed different population genetic structure and demographic histories. However, to this point, no attempt has been undertaken to compare phylogeographic population structure of these species, when collected from the same localities and at the same time. Furthermore, for both species population data are missing from the North African coast. Therefore, both morphometric and population genetic investigations are being carried out. Not only new insights into the evolutionary history of both species will be obtained from the African Mediterranean coasts, but also new biogeographical barriers will probably be revealed. A comparative phylogeography of two species with different larval stages will give us a better idea on the effect of larval duration on the dispersal capacity as well as on the variation of genetic polymorphism, and generation of local endemisms within natural populations. More recently, a third species from the rocky intertidal, Eriphia verrucosa, is included within this comparative analysis. Figure 1: Carcinus aestuarii Figure 2: Pachygrapsus marmoratus Materials and methods: Owing to the fact that population genetic investigations have so far focused only on the European Mediterranean coast, we try to cover almost the entire distrubition area of both species and thus my emphasis is to include the African Mediterranean counterparts. In addition to multivariate comparisons of linear morphometric characters among populations of both species from the Tunisian coasts (which show substantial morphological variation and differentiation), two molecular markers of different variability are used in the current investigation: the mitochondrial COI gene and nuclear microsattelite loci. Preliminary results and expected future work This study shows similar patterns of morphological differentiation in both species, with a separation of northwestern from southeastern populations, but clearly different patterns in genetic diversity and phylogeographic structure between both species along this geographical range (Figure 3 and 4). This requires discerning among possible factors that can be responsible for such diverging patterns of regional diversification. Figure 3: TCS network for the green crab Carcinus aestuarii Figure 4: TCS network for the marbled crab Pachygrapsus marmoratus Other ongoing research topics Population genetic structure of the common littoral prawn Palaemon elegans (Figure 5) (Crustacea: Caridea: Palaemonidae) in the southern Mediterranean Sea. Figure 5: Palaemon elegans Impressum

Universität Regensburg - Lehrstuhl Heinze - Biologie Home Aktuelles Mitarbeiter Forschung Lehre Literatur Links Miriam Brandt Coevolution?re Wechselwirkungen zwischen einer sozialparasitischen Ameisenart und ihren Wirten Mein Projekt besch?ftigt sich mit coevolution?ren Wechselwirkungen zwischen dem nordamerikanischen Sklavenhalter Protomognathus americanus und seinen Wirten, Leptothorax longispinosus, L. curvispinosus, und L. ambiguus. P. americanus ist als obligater Sklavenhalter in seinem Lebenszyklus v?llig von seinen Wirtsarten abh?ngig. Zur Koloniegr?ndung dringt eine begattete Jungk?nigin in ein Wirtsnest ein, vertreibt oder t?tet die K?nigin und die erwachsenen Arbeiterinnen und ?bernimmt deren Brut. Wenn diese schl?pft, akzeptieren die versklavten Wirtsarbeiterinnen die neue K?nigin und ?bernehmen alle notwendigen T?tigkeiten wie Brutpflege und Nahrungssuche, zu denen die Sklavenhalter-Arbeiterinnen nicht in der Lage sind. Letztere erf?llen nur eine Aufgabe: sie f?hren in periodischen Abst?nden Raubz?ge durch, in denen sie Puppen und Larven von benachbarten Wirtsnestern stehlen, um so neue Sklaven zu erhalten. Da diese Raubz?ge f?r die Wirte hohe Fitnessverluste mit sich bringen (sie verlieren die Brut eines Jahres, und zudem k?nnen die K?nigin und/oder Arbeiterinnen get?tet werden), hat dieses System das Potential f?r ein evolution?res Wettr?sten. Protomognathus americanus Leptothorax longispinosus Ich untersuche die wechselseitigen Selektionsdr?cke in diesem mutma?lichen Coevolutions-Proze? mit vier verschiedenen Ans?tzen. Durch Feldmanipulationen von Sklavenhalterdichten soll direkt der Einflu? des Sozialparasiten auf die demographische und genetische Struktur von Wirtspopulationen ermittelt werden. In Verhaltensbeobachtungen von Raubz?gen im Labor werden Unterschiede zwischen Sklavenhaltern und Wirten aus Populationen mit unterschiedlichem Parasitendruck sowie aus Populationen mit verschiedenen Wirtsarten dokumentiert, um eventuelle lokale Anpassungen zu zeigen. Weiterhin benutze ich populationsgenetische Methoden, um herauszufinden, ob eine Spezialisierung auf eine bestimmte Wirtsart auch zu einer Substrukturierung der Sklavenhalter-Population gef?hrt hat. Mit Hilfe von Gaschromatographie untersuche ich zwei Aspekte der Biologie des Sklavenhalters. Zum einen analysiere ich das Dufour-Dr?sensekret, das die Sklavenhalter einsetzen, um w?hrend eines Raubzuges Panik in der ?berfallenen Wirtskolonie auszul?sen. Zum anderen suche ich nach Unterschieden im kutikul?ren Kohlenwasserstoff-Profil von Sklavenhalter-K?niginnen, die bei verschiedenen Wirtsarten aufgewachsen sind, da dies ein Faktor ist, der eine m?gliche Wirtsspezialisierung des Sozialparasiten verst?rken k?nnte.

Zum anderen suche ich nach Unterschieden im kutikul?ren Kohlenwasserstoff-Profil von Sklavenhalter-K?niginnen, die bei verschiedenen Wirtsarten aufgewachsen sind, da dies ein Faktor ist, der eine m?gliche Wirtsspezialisierung des Sozialparasiten verst?rken k?nnte.

Universität Regensburg - Lehrstuhl Heinze - Biologie Home News Staff Research Teaching Publications Links Miriam Brandt Coevolutionary interactions between a social parasite and its hosts My project investigates the coevolutionary interactions between the obligatory slavemaking ant Protomognathus americanus and its hosts, Leptothorax longispinosus, L. ambiguus, and L. curvispinosus. P. americanus, which occurs throughout the Northeastern US and Canada, has a life-cycle that relies completely on one of its three potential host species. A slavemaker colony is started when a freshly mated queen enters a host colony, drives away the resident queen and workers and appropriates the brood. When the "enslaved" host workers hatch, they accept the new queen and carry out all the necessary work of foraging and brood care, which slavemaker workers are incapable of. The latter fulfil only one task: they conduct periodical raids on neighbouring host nests and steal worker pupae and larvae to replenish their supply of slaves. Since these raids impose severe fitness costs on the host colonies (loss of one year's brood, death of workers and/or the queen) and the parasite thus exerts a severe impact on its host, this system has the potential for an evolutionary arms race. Protomognathus americanus Leptothorax longispinosus I study the reciprocal selection pressures involved in this putative coevolutionary process incorporating four different approaches. Field manipulations of slavemaker densities are conducted to directly measure the influence of the parasite on the demographic and genetic composition of host populations. By means of behavioural observations of raids, slavemaker and host workers from populations with varying parasite density and from populations of different host species will be compared to reveal possible local adaptations. To complement these results, I employ population genetic methods to assess whether a specialization on a certain host has lead to a population substructuring in the slavemaker. Finally, I use gas chromatography to investigate two aspects of the slavemakers' biology. First, I analyse the Dufour's gland pheromones that slavemakers use to invoke panic in the host colony during raids. Second, I investigate the colony odour of slavemaker queens raised by different host species, since this is a factor that may potentially enhance the possibility of host-mediated speciation in the parasite.

Universität Regensburg - Lehrstuhl Heinze - Biologie Home News Staff Research Teaching Publications Links Birgit Fischer Interactions between virulence of social parasites and resistence of the hosts Date of birth: 17.04.1975 1986 - 1995 Gymnasium Zwiesel (highschool degree) 1995 - 2001 study of biology at University of Regensburg diploma thesis: "Coevolution between Harpagoxenus sublaevis and its host Leptothorax acervorum" (supervisor: Prof. J?rgen Heinze, University of Regensburg) since June 2001: PhD at University of Regensburg, Biology I (supervisor: Prof. J. Heinze and Dr. Susanne Foitzik) "Interactions between virulence of social parasites and resistance of the hosts" Picture 1: Harpagoxenus sublaevis Permanently parasitic species like the slavemaker Harpagoxenus sublaevis depend upon their hosts throughout their lives. Workers of the slave-making ant H. sublaevis raid neighboring colonies of their host species Leptothorax acervorum, Leptothorax muscorum and Leptothorax gredleri, defeat the adult workers and carry back the brood to their own nest. Slaves hatch from the stolen brood and care for the offspring of another species. The enormous parasite pressure should provoke resistance characters in the host species in strongly parasitized populations. In behavioural studies we examined whether host colonies from three populations (Germany, Russia and England) varied in the effectiveness of their nest defence against the slavemaker. Importantly, the slavemaker H. sublaevis does not occur in England, but in Germany and Russia, so that the English population should be "naive". We found that host colonies from England, when confronted with a single slavemaker, reacted much more aggressively. They bit and killed the slavemaker more often than host colonies from Germany or Russia. It is now the question whether the host colonies from England have developed a resistance against the slavemaker or whether the higher aggressiveness is a preadaptation, which made the colonization of England more difficult for the slavemaker. Picture 2: Workers of the host species Leptothorax acervorum fighting against a slavemaker In following projects I will examine possible differences in the effectiveness of nest defence of the two main host-species Leptothorax acervorum and Leptothorax muscorum related to nest demography and colony size. I will do this by mapping, density manipulations and genetic analyses ofs a population in Abensberg, Germany.

Heinze and Dr. Susanne Foitzik) "Interactions between virulence of social parasites and resistance of the hosts" Picture 1: Harpagoxenus sublaevis Permanently parasitic species like the slavemaker Harpagoxenus sublaevis depend upon their hosts throughout their lives. Workers of the slave-making ant H. sublaevis raid neighboring colonies of their host species Leptothorax acervorum, Leptothorax muscorum and Leptothorax gredleri, defeat the adult workers and carry back the brood to their own nest. Slaves hatch from the stolen brood and care for the offspring of another species. The enormous parasite pressure should provoke resistance characters in the host species in strongly parasitized populations. In behavioural studies we examined whether host colonies from three populations (Germany, Russia and England) varied in the effectiveness of their nest defence against the slavemaker. Importantly, the slavemaker H. sublaevis does not occur in England, but in Germany and Russia, so that the English population should be "naive". We found that host colonies from England, when confronted with a single slavemaker, reacted much more aggressively. They bit and killed the slavemaker more often than host colonies from Germany or Russia. It is now the question whether the host colonies from England have developed a resistance against the slavemaker or whether the higher aggressiveness is a preadaptation, which made the colonization of England more difficult for the slavemaker. Picture 2: Workers of the host species Leptothorax acervorum fighting against a slavemaker In following projects I will examine possible differences in the effectiveness of nest defence of the two main host-species Leptothorax acervorum and Leptothorax muscorum related to nest demography and colony size. I will do this by mapping, density manipulations and genetic analyses ofs a population in Abensberg, Germany.

Universität Regensburg - Lehrstuhl Heinze - Biologie Home Aktuelles Mitarbeiter Forschung Lehre Literatur Links Birgit Fischer Wechselwirkungen zwischen Virulenz von Sozialparasiten und Resistenz der Wirte Geb. 17.04.1975 in Zwiesel (Bayr. Wald) 1986 - 1995 Gymnasium Zwiesel 1995 - 2001 Biologiestudium an der Universit?t Regensburg Diplomarbeit: "Koevolution zwischen dem Sklavenhalter Harpagoxenus sublaevis und seinem Hauptwirt Leptothorax acervorum" bei Prof. J?rgen Heinze in Regensburg Seit Juni 2001: Doktorarbeit an der Universit?t Regensburg, Biologie I unter der Betreuung von Prof. J?rgen Heinze und Dr. Susanne Foitzik mit dem Thema "Wechselwirkungen zwischen Virulenz von Sozialparasiten und Resistenz der Wirte" Bild 1: Harpagoxenus sublaevis Ich untersuche in meiner Arbeit die dulotisch lebende (Dulosis = Sklavenhaltertum) Ameise Harpagoxenus sublaevis. Sklavenhalter wie H. sublaevis sind obligat auf ihren Wirt angewiesen, d.h. sie unternehmen periodische Sklavenraubzüge in Nachbarnester ihrer Wirtsarten Leptothorax acervorum, Leptothorax muscorum und Leptothorax gredleri, um deren Brut zu erbeuten. Diese schlüpfen in dem Sklavenhalternest und verrichten dort arbeiterinnen-typische Arbeiten. Da der Selektionsdruck durch die Parasiten sehr groß ist, sollten die Wirte Resistenzmechanismen gegenüber dem Sklavenhalter entwickeln. Im Rahmen von Verhaltensversuchen während meiner Diplomarbeit sollte festgestellt werden, ob es durch die Anwesenheit eines Sozialparasiten wie Harpagoxenus sublaevis in einer Wirtspopulation von Leptothorax acervorum zu Adaptationen bzw. zu Gegenadaptationen von Seiten der Sklavenhalter gekommen ist. Entscheidend war, dass eine der untersuchten Wirtspopulationen aus einem sozialparasitenfreien Gebiet stammt, d.h. "naiv" war. Meine Untersuchungen ergaben, dass Wirtskolonien einer englischen, nicht-parasitierten Population sehr viel aggressiver auf den Sklavenhalter reagieren und eingedrungene Sklavenhalterinnen deutlich häufiger töten als Wirtskolonien aus parasitierten Populationen aus Deutschland und Russland. Allerdings unterschieden sich die Kampfstrategien nicht zwischen den drei Populationen, so dass die Frage offen bleibt, wie es den englischen Wirten gelingt, sich effektiver gegen den Sklavenhalter zu wehren. Bild 2: Arbeiterinnen der Wirtsart Leptothorax acervorum im Kampf gegen eine eingedrungene Sklavenhalterin Als weitere Projekte soll das Abwehrverhalten der beiden Wirtsarten Leptothorax acervorum und Leptothorax muscorum hinsichtlich ihrer Sozialstruktur und Koloniegröße untersucht und miteinander verglichen werden. Dies wird durch großflächige Kartierungen, Dichtemanipulationen und populationsgenetische Analysen einer Population in Abensberg untersucht.

Universität Regensburg - Lehrstuhl Heinze - Biologie Home Aktuelles Mitarbeiter Forschung Lehre Literatur Links Dr. Susanne Foitzik Adresse LS Biologie 1 Universit?t Regensburg Universit?tsstrasse 31 D-93040 Regensburg Germany Email: Susanne.Foitzik@biologie.uni-regensburg.de Tel: +49 (0)941 943 2152 Fax: +49 (0)941 943 3304 Beim Ameisensammeln Zur Person 31.07. 1970 Geburtstag Mai 1989 Abitur 1989-1995 Studium der Biologie an der Julius Maximilians Universit?t in W?rzburg 1992-1993 Stipendium des DAAD f?r das Studium an der State University of New York in Albany, USA M?rz 1995 Diplom in W?rzburg; Betreuung der Diplomarbeit mit dem Thema: "Konkurrenz und Einnischung bei Arten der Gattung Leptothorax" durch Prof. B. H?lldobler und Dr. J. Heinze. Juni 1998 Dissertation unter Anleitung von Prof. B. H?lldobler und Dr. J. Heinze, Thema: "Populationsstruktur und Investition in Geschlechtstiere bei der Ameise Leptothorax nylanderi". 7/1998 - 4/2000 Post-Doc in der Arbeitsgruppe von Prof. Joan M. Herbers, Colorado State University, Fort Collins, USA Seit 1. 5. 2000 wissenschaftliche Assistentin (C1) am LS Biologie I, Universit?t Regensburg (Prof. Dr. J. Heinze). Forschungsinteressen ?kologie, Evolution, Verhalten, Soziogenetik und Phylogeographie von Ameisen, Koevolution zwischen Sozialparasiten und deren Wirten, Reproduktive Taktiken von M?nnchen und K?niginnen, Investition in Geschlechtstiere, Kolonieerkennung, Populationsstruktur Aktuelle Forschungsprojekte Koevolution?re Interaktionen zwischen Sozialparasiten und deren Wirtsarten Koevolution zwischen Parasiten und deren Wirten wird zur Zeit stark diskutiert. In den letzten Jahren konnten Untersuchungen an V?geln zeigen, dass Wirte von Brutparasiten Abwehrmechanismen entwickeln, die zu Gegenanpassungen bei Parasiten f?hren. Bei sozialen Insekten hingegen wurde ein vergleichbares Wirt-Parasit System im Hinblick auf ein koevolution?res Wettrennen noch nicht untersucht. Neueste Studien zeigen jedoch, dass der Einfluss der Sklavenhalter Protomognathus americanus und Harpagoxenus sublaevis auf ihre Wirtsarten der Gattung Leptothorax sehr gro? sein kann. Als Reaktion auf einen hohen Selektionsdruck durch zahlreiche, destruktive Raubz?ge konnten Verhaltensanpassungen und ?nderungen im Kolonieaufbau, der Soziogenetik und Sozialstruktur gezeigt werden. In Freilandversuchen wird nun direkt der Einfluss der Sozialparasiten auf die demographische und genetische Zusammensetzung von Wirtspopulationen getestet, indem die Sklavenhalterdichte lokal manipuliert wird. Au?erdem werden die Raubzugsinteraktionen zwischen Sklavenhaltern und Wirtsarbeiterinnen aus unparasitierten und stark parasitierten Gebieten verglichen. Versuche mit Kolonien aus Gebieten mit einer zweiten Wirtsart wurden einbezogen, um zu zeigen, dass verschiedene Wirtsarten unterschiedliche Verhaltensadaptationen entwickelt haben. Auch gibt es erste Hinweise auf wirtsspezifische Anpassungen bei Sozialparasiten. Populationsgenetische Studien sollen Aufschluss dar?ber geben, ob eine Wirtsspezialisierung zu einer Populations-Substrukturierung gef?hrt hat. Mit gaschromatographischen Methoden werden Pheromone, die w?hrend der Raubz?ge eingesetzt werden, analysiert. An diesen Projekten sind die Diplom-Biologinnen Birgit Fischer und Miriam Brandt beteiligt. Sklavenhalterkolonie (slavemaker colony) Reproduktive Taktiken bei Ameisen der Gattung Hypoponera Sexuelle Selektion hat bei vielen Arten dazu gef?hrt, dass Geschlechter, oder seltener auch Tiere desselben Geschlechts, unterschiedliche reproduktiven Taktiken oder Morphologien aufweisen. Konditionelle Strategien dieser Art treten zumeist bei M?nnchen auf, nur selten sind sie bei Weibchen zu beobachten. Bei der Ameisengattung Hypoponera sind alternative reproduktive Taktiken sowohl bei K?niginnen als auch bei M?nnchen zu finden. W?hrend sich gefl?gelte Geschlechtstiere in Hochzeitfl?gen paaren, sichern bis zu zwei Morphen fl?gelloser M?nnchen ihren reproduktiven Erfolg durch innernestliche Paarungen mit fl?gellosen Weibchen. Mit Hilfe genetischer, verhaltensbiologischer und ?kologischer Methoden wird gekl?rt werden, welche Faktoren zu dieser Vielfalt gef?hrt haben. Beispielhaft wird zun?chst an einer Art, H. opacior, untersucht werden, unter welchen Bedingungen gefl?gelte bzw. fl?gellose Geschlechtstiere auftreten. Mit genetischen Methoden wird die Heritabilit?t der Morphen, die Koloniestruktur und die Auswirkungen von Inzucht untersucht werden. Manipulation ?kologischer Faktoren im Freiland wie auch bei Laborkolonien werden den Einfluss der Umwelt auf die Produktion der Geschlechtstiermorphen analysieren. Verhaltensexperimente werden das Bewacherverhalten fl?gelloser M?nnchen genauer beleuchten. Eine phylogenetische Studie schlie?lich wird feststellen, ob verschiedene reproduktive Taktiken mehrfach konvergent innerhalb der Gattung entstanden sind. Dazu werden Arten mit verschiedenen Geschlechtstiermorphen (z.B. mit gefl?gelten, k?mpfenden oder bewachenden M?nnchen) genetisch, morphologisch und histologisch untersucht. Universität Regensburg - Lehrstuhl Heinze - Biologie Home News Staff Research Teaching Publications Links Dr. Susanne Foitzik Address LS Biologie 1 Universit?t Regensburg Universit?tsstrasse 31 D-93040 Regensburg Germany Email: Susanne.Foitzik@biologie.uni-regensburg.de Tel: +49 (0)941 943 2152 Fax: +49 (0)941 943 3304 Curriculum Vitae 31.07. 1970 Date of birth May 1989 High School degree 11/1989- 3/1995 Student at the Julius Maximilian University in W?rzburg, Subject: Biology 1992-1993 Fellowship of the German Academic Exchange Service to study in the graduate program of State University of New York in Albany, USA March 1995 Final examination in W?rzburg; Diploma thesis with the title: "Competition and evolutionary niches of species of the genus Leptothorax " Scientific advisers: Prof. B. H?lldobler and Dr. J. Heinze. 5/1995 - 6/1998 Ph D Thesis at the Julius Maximilian University in W?rzburg under supervision of Prof. B. H?lldobler and Dr. J. Heinze; Title: "Population structure and sex allocation in the ant species Leptothorax nylanderi". 7/1998 - 4/2000 Post-Doc in the group of Prof. Joan M. Herbers, Colorado State University, Fort Collins, USA Since 1.5.2000 scientific assistant in the department Biology I (Prof. Dr. J. Heinze), University of Regensburg Research interests Ecology, Evolution, Behaviour, Sociogenetic and phylogeography of ants. Coevolution between social parasites and their hosts, reproductive tactics of males and queens, sex allocation patterns, nest mate recognition, population structure. Recent research projects Coevolutionary interactions between social parasites and their hosts Coevolution between parasites and their hosts has been strongly debated in recent years. New studies on birds could demonstrate that hosts of avian brood parasites can develop defence mechanisms, which can be counteracted by the parasites. In social insects, however, a similar parasite-host system has not been studied under the perspective of a co-evolutionary arms race. Recent investigations show a strong impact of the slavemakers Protomognathus americanus and Harpagoxenus sublaevis on their Leptothorax host species. Behavioural adaptations, as well as changes in the genetic, social and demographic composition of host colonies could be demonstrated as a reaction to a high parasite pressure via frequent and destructive raids. In field studies the impact of the social parasite on the demographic and genetic composition of host populations will be investigated by manipulating slavemaker density locally. Additionally behavioural interactions that occur during raids of slavemakers and hosts from parasitized and unparasitized populations will be analysed. Colonies from areas with a second host species were included to test whether different host species develop different defence mechanisms and whether the parasite is adapted to its primary host. A population genetic study will investigate whether host specificity has developed in certain populations of the social parasite. Gas chromatography will help to analyse the chemical weapons the slavemakers use during raids. The Diplom-biologists Birgit Fischer and Miriam Brandt are collaborating on these projects. slavemaker colony Reproductive tactics in Hypoponera ants In many animals, males have evolved weapons, elaborate courtship displays, or costly ornaments to increase their reproductive success. Ants, in contrast, commonly mate during nuptial flights, in which males do not profit from fighting or attempting to monopolize females. However, where mating occurs in the nest, males can use other reproductive tactics. Here, we document that wingless (apterous) males of Hypoponera opacior sit on top of queen cocoons, insert their genitalia into the cocoons and remain in copula for days with cocooned queens. These males were tolerant of each other; fighting was never recorded. Our observations therefore suggest that wingless males of H. opacior ensure reproduction by copulatory mate guarding. This strategy, though time-consuming, presumably reduces the likelihood of subsequent inseminations by other males. Apterous H. opacior males have only a limited amount of sperm available: we show histological that, contrary to Cardiocondyla fighter males, the testes degenerate in early adult life. Males of H. opacior have relatively few mating opportunities. Although some wingless males were reproductively active over more than three weeks, we observed a maximum of only six matings per male, with a mean slightly above one. Some H. opacior males employ an alternative reproductive tactic of dispersal and outbreeding. We found colonies headed by single, dealate queens, which did not raise wingless sexuals but presumably reproduce through winged reproductives, that mate in nuptial flights. The social structure of those colonies stood in stark contrast to nests containing wingless reproductives, which were highly polygynous and polydomous. Universität Regensburg - Lehrstuhl Heinze - Biologie Home News Staff Research Teaching Publications Links Dr. Susanne Foitzik Address LS Biologie 1 Universit?t Regensburg Universit?tsstrasse 31 D-93040 Regensburg Germany Email: Susanne.Foitzik@biologie.uni-regensburg.de Tel: +49 (0)941 943 2152 Fax: +49 (0)941 943 3304 Curriculum Vitae 31.07. 1970 Date of birth May 1989 High School degree 11/1989- 3/1995 Student at the Julius Maximilian University in W?rzburg, Subject: Biology 1992-1993 Fellowship of the German Academic Exchange Service to study in the graduate program of State University of New York in Albany, USA March 1995 Final examination in W?rzburg; Diploma thesis with the title: "Competition and evolutionary niches of species of the genus Leptothorax " Scientific advisers: Prof. B. H?lldobler and Dr. J. Heinze. 5/1995 - 6/1998 Ph D Thesis at the Julius Maximilian University in W?rzburg under supervision of Prof. B. H?lldobler and Dr. J. Heinze; Title: "Population structure and sex allocation in the ant species Leptothorax nylanderi". 7/1998 - 4/2000 Post-Doc in the group of Prof. Joan M. Herbers, Colorado State University, Fort Collins, USA Since 1.5.2000 scientific assistant in the department Biology I (Prof. Dr. J. Heinze), University of Regensburg Research interests Ecology, Evolution, Behaviour, Sociogenetic and phylogeography of ants. Coevolution between social parasites and their hosts, reproductive tactics of males and queens, sex allocation patterns, nest mate recognition, population structure. Recent research projects Coevolutionary interactions between social parasites and their hosts Coevolution between parasites and their hosts has been strongly debated in recent years. New studies on birds could demonstrate that hosts of avian brood parasites can develop defence mechanisms, which can be counteracted by the parasites. In social insects, however, a similar parasite-host system has not been studied under the perspective of a co-evolutionary arms race. Recent investigations show a strong impact of the slavemakers Protomognathus americanus and Harpagoxenus sublaevis on their Leptothorax host species. Behavioural adaptations, as well as changes in the genetic, social and demographic composition of host colonies could be demonstrated as a reaction to a high parasite pressure via frequent and destructive raids. In field studies the impact of the social parasite on the demographic and genetic composition of host populations will be investigated by manipulating slavemaker density locally. Additionally behavioural interactions that occur during raids of slavemakers and hosts from parasitized and unparasitized populations will be analysed. Colonies from areas with a second host species were included to test whether different host species develop different defence mechanisms and whether the parasite is adapted to its primary host. A population genetic study will investigate whether host specificity has developed in certain populations of the social parasite. Gas chromatography will help to analyse the chemical weapons the slavemakers use during raids. The Diplom-biologists Birgit Fischer and Miriam Brandt are collaborating on these projects. slavemaker colony Reproductive tactics in Hypoponera ants In many animals, males have evolved weapons, elaborate courtship displays, or costly ornaments to increase their reproductive success. Ants, in contrast, commonly mate during nuptial flights, in which males do not profit from fighting or attempting to monopolize females. However, where mating occurs in the nest, males can use other reproductive tactics. Here, we document that wingless (apterous) males of Hypoponera opacior sit on top of queen cocoons, insert their genitalia into the cocoons and remain in copula for days with cocooned queens. These males were tolerant of each other; fighting was never recorded. Our observations therefore suggest that wingless males of H. opacior ensure reproduction by copulatory mate guarding. This strategy, though time-consuming, presumably reduces the likelihood of subsequent inseminations by other males. Apterous H. opacior males have only a limited amount of sperm available: we show histological that, contrary to Cardiocondyla fighter males, the testes degenerate in early adult life. Males of H. opacior have relatively few mating opportunities. Although some wingless males were reproductively active over more than three weeks, we observed a maximum of only six matings per male, with a mean slightly above one. Some H. opacior males employ an alternative reproductive tactic of dispersal and outbreeding. We found colonies headed by single, dealate queens, which did not raise wingless sexuals but presumably reproduce through winged reproductives, that mate in nuptial flights. The social structure of those colonies stood in stark contrast to nests containing wingless reproductives, which were highly polygynous and polydomous. Universität Regensburg - Lehrstuhl Heinze - Biologie Home Aktuelles Mitarbeiter Forschung Lehre Literatur Links Alexander Fuchs Curriculum Vitae 1995 ? 2001: Studium der Biologie an der Universität Regensburg 1998 ? 1999: Studium an der University of Colorado in Boulder, USA Betreuerin: Prof. D. Bowers Diplomarbeit: Iridoide Glycoside ? Ihre Bedeutung für die Systematik der Asteridae s. lat. und ihre Induktion in Plantago lanceolata Betreuer: Prof. A. Bresinsky Dr. M. Fischer seit Sept. 2001: Promotion an der Universität Regensburg, Biologie I Betreuerin: Dr. J. Korb Forschung Der Einfluss des Verwandtschaftsgrads auf die Aufrechterhaltung der Eusozialität bei der Termite Cryptotermes secundus Cryptotermes secundus gehört zu den one-piece-type Termiten und kommt in den Mangroven (Ceriops tagal) im Norden Australiens (Darwin) vor. C. secundus zeigt im Laufe ihrer Ontogenese eine erstaunliche Flexibilität hinsichtlich ihres Entwicklungsendpunkts (Abbildung 1+2), wodurch sich einem Individuum verschiedene reproduktive Taktiken eröffnen: es kann entweder als Helfer in der Kolonie bleiben, sich zum Ersatzgeschlechtstier oder Soldat entwickeln oder die Kolonie als geflügeltes Geschlechtstier verlassen. Obwohl jeweils nur ein Paar Geschlechtstiere eine Kolonie gründet, findet man in der Natur sowohl monogame als auch polygame Kolonien. Polygame Kolonien sind also nicht das Resultat von Pleometrose (= mehrere Königinnen, die sich nach der Nestgründung gemeinsam um die Brut kümmern), sondern sie entstehen durch die Fusion von 2 oder mehr Kolonien. Diese Kolonien waren zwar ursprünglich getrennt angelegt worden, sind dann jedoch im Laufe der Zeit, bedingt durch ihre räumliche Nähe, miteinander verschmolzen. Diese Koloniefusionen laufen nach unserem Wissen friedlich ab, ohne dass sich die Angehörigen der beiden Kolonien bekämpfen. Da sich in einer derartigen Kolonie Individuen mit unterschiedlichem Verwandtschaftsgrad finden, ist es nun interessant, ob sich nah verwandte Individuen anders zueinander verhalten als entfernter verwandte (kin discrimination). Auch die reproduktive Taktik eines Individuums könnte sich in der Folge ändern, da der Verwandtschaftsgrad insgesamt innerhalb der Kolonie sinkt (unter der Annahme, dass die Gründerpaare nicht nah miteinander verwandt waren). Königin von Cryptotermes secundus Projekte (1) Die Bedeutung des Verwandtschaftsgrads Momentan entwickle ich Mikrosatelliten als genetische Marker, um die Verwandtschaft der Individuen in einer Kolonie bestimmen zu können und um die folgenden Fragen zu beantworten: - Bestehen Unterschiede im Verhalten zwischen Individuen in monogamen und polygamen Kolonien? - Findet sich in polygamen Kolonien, mit näher und entfernter verwandten Individuen, Verwandtenselektion? - Kann eine der Königinnen in polygamen Kolonien die Fortpflanzung monopolisieren? (2) Computer-Tomographie und Verhaltensbeobachtungen Bis dato war es nicht möglich, C. secundus in seinem natürlichen Habitat, d.h. im Holz, zu beobachten. Mit Hilfe von CT-Aufnahmen in Verbindung mit einer endoskopischen Kamera war es mir jedoch möglich, C. secundus in Pinus radiata-Blöcken direkt zu beobachten (Film). Mit Hilfe von CT-Aufnahmen und der Endoskopie möchte ich: - die Fraßgeschwindigkeit von C. secundus-Kolonien bestimmen - die Kolonie-Entwicklung und die Nest-Architektur beschreiben - Langzeitbeobachtungen und Verhaltensversuche an den Termiten im Holz durchführen 3d- dimensionale Rekonstruktion der CT-Schichtbilder eines Cryptotermes secundus Nests (* : vorgebohrte Kammer, in welche die Termiten ursprünglich gesetzt wurden) Das Projekt wird durch ein Emmy Noether Stipendium der Deutschen Forschungsgemeinschaft (DFG) unterst?tzt.

Universität Regensburg - Lehrstuhl Heinze - Biologie Home News Staff Research Teaching Publications Links Alexander Fuchs Curriculum Vitae 1995 ? 2001: study of biology at the University of Regensburg 1998 ? 1999: study at the University of Colorado, Boulder, USA Supervisor: Prof. D. Bowers Diploma thesis: ?Iridoid Glycosides ? their importance for the systematics of the Asteridae s. lat. and their induction in Plantago lanceolata? Supervisors: Prof. A. Bresinsky Dr. M. Fischer Since 2001: PhD at the University of Regensburg, Biology I Supervisor: Dr. J. Korb Research Leave or stay ? The influence of relatedness on the maintenance of eusociality in termites Study species My study species, Cryptotermes secundus, belongs to the OP-termites and it occurs naturally in the mangroves (Ceriops tagal) of Northern Australia (Darwin). The most striking feature of these termites is that they do have a high developmental flexibility and thus several developmental tactics (figure 1+2). Although in this species colonies are founded by a single reproductive pair, both monogamous and polygamous colonies can be found in the field. Polygamous colonies are thus not the result of pleometrosis (= an aggregation of several queens in the founding phase to collectively care for the brood), but usually stem from colony fusion. This occurs when one log was by chance colonised by two or more founding pairs in close proximity. Interestingly no antagonism can be observed when colonies fuse. Nevertheless one might expect to see some differences in the behavioural patterns between more closely and more distantly related individuals. An individual?s developmental tactic might also change as overall relatedness in a colony is reduced after colony fusion (given that the founding pairs are not closely related to each other). Queen of Cryptotermes secundus Projects: (1) Influence of relatedness Currently I am developing microsatellite genetic markers to determine within-colony relatedness and answer the following questions: - Are there behavioural differences between monogamous and polygamous colonies? - Do more closely and more distantly related individuals behave differently to each other? Thus do we see kin discrimination? - Is reproduction monopolized in polygamous colonies by a single queen? (2) Computer tomography and behavioural observations Observation of C. secundus in its natural habitat, i.e. within the wood, was impossible so far. However, the combination of two techniques, generally applied in the medical sector, computer tomography and endoscopy, made it possible to observe C. secundus directly within blocks of Pinus radiata (film) and will hopefully help us to: - determine wood consumption rates of C. secundus colonies - show patterns of colony development and nest architecture - perform long-term behavioural observations within the wood blocks 3d-reconstruction of a Cryptotermes secundus nest from CT images (* : pre-drilled chamber for colony establishment) The project is supported by an Emmy Noether Grant from the German Science Foundation (DFG).

Universität Regensburg - Lehrstuhl Heinze - Biologie Home News Staff Research Teaching Publications Links Luise Heine Curriculum vitae 2005 starting the diploma thesis on the Jamaican bromeliad crab Metopaulias depressus under the supervision of Dr. C. Schubart 2004 study abroad, semester at the University of Queensland, Brisbane 2000 entering the University of Regensburg to explore the depths of biology 2000 graduation at the Gabelsberger Gymnasium Mainburg The Jamaican bromeliad crab, Metopaulias depressus (Decapoda, Brachyura, Sesarmidae), lives exclusively in the rainwater-storing leaf axils of bromeliad plants. The crabs forms a colony on the plant, consisting of one breeding mother crab and her offspring in different age groups. To ensure reproduction in this hostile and scattered microhabitat, the species evolved a high degree of parental care. The parental care includes a) cleaning the leaf axil from litter, b) circulating the water to enrich it with O2, c) hunting snails and arthropods to feed the young, d) carrying snail shells into the leaf axils in order to buffer the pH of the water and to enrich it with calcium, which is needed for moulting as well as e) defending the colony from predators and possible intruders, which would be other crabs. Consequently, it is very time and energy consuming to raise offspring. My research consists of establishing genetic relationships within and between colonies with different genetic markers (mtDNA sequences and microsatellites). On one hand, it shall be determined whether the different-sized juveniles are all the offspring of the reproductive female inhabiting the plant and thus whether this crab species can be considered to have evolved a social helper system with delayed juvenile dispersal. On the other hand, it shall be tested with population genetic methods how far the crabs are able to migrate and therefore how strong the gene flow between the different parts of the island is.

Universität Regensburg - Lehrstuhl Heinze - Biologie Home News Staff Research Teaching Publications Links Ruth Jesse Ruth Jesse 5/2000: German high school degree (Abitur) at the Rottmayr Gymnasium in Laufen 10/2000 - 4/2001: Au pair in Sydney, Australia 10/2001 - Study Biology at the University of Regensburg (to be finished in 2006) In my Diplom studies, I want to make a contribution to the conservation of Potamon fluviatile. This freshwater crab can be found in fresh waters throughout the north-central Mediterranean area (Italy, Malta, Serbia to western Greece). During the past twenty years, this species has experienced a noticeable decrease within its entire distribution range, to the point of completely disappearing in some waters. One possible way to slow down or counteract this negative development, would be to recolonise rivers and lakes, from which the crabs have disappeared. Together with Italian colleagues from the University of Florence, Christoph Schubart wants to establish necessary measurements for the management and conservation of Potamon fluviatile in Italy. To apply stocking and re-introduction initiatives successfully, it is necessary to carry out population genetic studies to document the genetic diversity of the species and search for regional endemisms. After collecting individuals from different populations in Italy, we extract tissue from a detached leg (which regenerates) and measure the animals. The study of genetic variability is conducted in order to be able to analyse differences in sequences of mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) using the NADH subunit I (NDH1) and cytochrome oxidase subunit I (COI). We are also planning to establish microsatellites for Potamon fluviatile. This will be done in collaboration with the University of Florence, where I will conduct laboratory work during two months in 2006 financed by a DAAD-Vigoni exchange program. Hopefully, our results will provide valuable Linksrmation for conservation agencies when planning recolonisation measurements for this endangered crab species!

Universität Regensburg - Lehrstuhl Heinze - Biologie Home News Staff Research Teaching Publications Links Ruth Jesse Ruth Jesse 5/2000: German high school degree (Abitur) at the Rottmayr Gymnasium in Laufen 10/2000 - 4/2001: Au pair in Sydney, Australia 10/2001 - Study Biology at the University of Regensburg (to be finished in 2006) In my Diplom studies, I want to make a contribution to the conservation of Potamon fluviatile. This freshwater crab can be found in fresh waters throughout the north-central Mediterranean area (Italy, Malta, Serbia to western Greece). During the past twenty years, this species has experienced a noticeable decrease within its entire distribution range, to the point of completely disappearing in some waters. One possible way to slow down or counteract this negative development, would be to recolonise rivers and lakes, from which the crabs have disappeared. Together with Italian colleagues from the University of Florence, Christoph Schubart wants to establish necessary measurements for the management and conservation of Potamon fluviatile in Italy. To apply stocking and re-introduction initiatives successfully, it is necessary to carry out population genetic studies to document the genetic diversity of the species and search for regional endemisms. After collecting individuals from different populations in Italy, we extract tissue from a detached leg (which regenerates) and measure the animals. The study of genetic variability is conducted in order to be able to analyse differences in sequences of mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) using the NADH subunit I (NDH1) and cytochrome oxidase subunit I (COI). We are also planning to establish microsatellites for Potamon fluviatile. This will be done in collaboration with the University of Florence, where I will conduct laboratory work during two months in 2006 financed by a DAAD-Vigoni exchange program. Hopefully, our results will provide valuable Linksrmation for conservation agencies when planning recolonisation measurements for this endangered crab species!

Universität Regensburg - Lehrstuhl Heinze - Biologie Home News Staff Research Teaching Publications Links The Pachycondyla Workgroup We are working on ant species of the genus Pachycondyla. The genus Pachycondyla is a good model system for the comparative study of key social traits. Its main features are primary polygyny, near-linear dominance hierarchies, small colony size, polydomy and they're easy to observe because of their size. Also, a difference has been shown between the chemical profile of queens and workers (D'Ettorre et al., 2004, Proc R Soc B 271: 1427-1434). We are studying the plasticity of queen behaviour, nepotism, sociogenetics, founding associations, the presence of a queen-marking pheromone, the chemical changes associated with ovary development and individual recognition. Dr. Patrizia d'Ettorre Jelle van Zweden Oliver Aehle Matthias F?rst Back to German Site

Universität Regensburg - Lehrstuhl Heinze - Biologie Home News Staff Research Teaching Publications Links Estelle Roux Person 1996 -1999 study of biology at Saint J?r?me University of Aix-Marseille, France. 1998: summer project at the chemical communication unit of the CNRS, Marseille: "Cuticular profiles in hierarchy of the lobster cockroach" (supervisors Dr. L. Sreng, Dr. E. Provost) 1999: ERASMUS year at Manchester University, UK: "Sexual selection in Fruit flies" (supervisor: Prof. R.J. Wood) 2000: master project at INRA, research center of Versailles, on "Mate recognition system in the green sting bug: is pheromone use for population discrimination by females?" (supervisor Dr. M. Renou) Since nov. 2000: PhD at the University of Regensburg, Biology 1 "Role of soldiers in the basal termite Cryptotermes secundus" (supervisor: Dr. J. Korb) Research Project : PLUG AND DIE ? is that the function of dry-wood termite soldiers? In the basal termite Cryptotermes secundus (Kalotermitidae) only one sterile caste is found: the soldier caste. It differs from the other colony members morphologically. The head is heavily sclerotised and pigmented and the mandibles are more developed than in helpers (i.e. individuals that assume the role of workers before they develop into reproductives). Besides, soldiers of the Kalotermitid family have a peculiar flat front head, almost as large as the galleries that they inhabit. This characteristic allows them to block a gallery with their head and act as living plug. Cryptotermes secundus soldier My project investigates the function of this particular caste in order to elucidate why the soldier caste is maintained. The absence of non-social Isoptera prevent us to directly investigate the origin of the evolution of this caste. To answer this main question I am looking at: What is the advantage of being a soldier? A set of experiment has been set up in the mangroves of Darwin (Australia) the natural habitat of this species, in order to measure fitness parameters of soldiers. This will tell us if soldiers gain indirect fitness by assuring a higher survival rate of the colony and also if they confer a better production rate of sexuals. Mangrove of Darwin 2. Are there some peculiar pressures that favour the presence of soldiers? In the field I have been looking at the presence of potential predators and competitors. No specific predators could be identified, even if ants are common they didn't show particular agonistic behaviour towards the termites. As colonies of this termite never exploit new food sources, wood-borer beetle larvae are our best inter-specific candidate as competitors with high impact on colony survival. Two helpers besides a soldier which palps a beetle larvae (intruder) 3. How do soldiers behave towards intruders? The proximate function of soldier is investigated with a series of behavioural experiments. First, the behaviour of soldiers and its colony is recorded in presence of a jewel beetle larvae. Second, intraspecific encounters will investigate the impact of direct competition and how this species deals with it. This project is supported by the DFG grant KO 1895/2-1 Additional links: Check list of termites (and more) A lot on Jewel Beetles Working within the EU

Universität Regensburg - Lehrstuhl Heinze - Biologie Home Aktuelles Mitarbeiter Forschung Lehre Literatur Links Markus Rüger Alternativ reproduktive Taktiken in der Ameisengattung Hypoponera: Die Evolution hat, anstelle immer nur einen "idealen" M?nnchen- und Weibchen-Typ in jeder Art zu favorisieren, teilweise eine extreme ph?notypische Diversit?t bez?glich Morphologie, Verhalten, Physiologie und Live History entstehen lassen. Vor allem die Sexuelle Selektion hat bei sehr vielen Arten dazu gef?hrt, dass der Fortpflanzungserfolg einzelner Individuen eines Geschlechts durch verschiedene Strategien erh?ht werden kann. Unter den Vertebraten ist beispielsweise ein "erschleichen" der Paarung durch schw?chere M?nnchen zu beobachten, die es nicht schaffen einen eigenen Harem zu monopolisieren oder einen Balzplatz zu verteidigen. Andere wiederum versuchen den Harems- bzw. Balzplatzbesitzer durch offene Aggression zu vertreiben um so ihren Fortpflanzungserfolg zu erh?hen. Auch innerhalb der Ameisen sind verschiedene Strategien anzutreffen (siehe auch Cremer S., Dr. D'Ettorre P., Schrempf A.). In diesem Sinne besonders reichhaltig ist die Gattung Hypoponera, in der es sowohl bei M?nnchen als auch bei K?niginnen ein gro?e F?lle reproduktiver Morphen und Taktiken gibt. Dieses Spektrum erstreckt sich von Arten mit einem als urspr?nglich betrachteten Hochzeits- und Verbreitungsflug gefl?gelter Geschlechtstiere ?ber Arten mit k?mpfenden M?nnchen hin zu Arten mit sowohl gefl?gelten als auch ungefl?gelten M?nnchen- und K?niginnenmorphen. In meiner Doktorarbeit untersuche ich zun?chst die alternativen reproduktiven Taktiken bei der Art Hypoponera opacior. Bei dieser Art treten sowohl gefl?gelte als auch ungefl?gelte M?nnchen und K?niginnen auf. Durch Herangehensweisen auf Genetischer-, ?kologischer und Verhaltensebene sollen die proximaten Ursachen f?r das Entstehen sowohl gefl?gelten als auch ungefl?gelten Geschlechtstiere aufgedeckt werden. Hypoponera opacior ist eine kleine ponerine Ameise, die ihre Nester bevorzugt unter Steinen etabliert und im Erdreich und dem ihm aufliegenden Laubstreu nach Nahrung sucht. Die f?r die Untersuchungen verwendeten Tiere stammen aus den Eichen- und Wacholderw?ldern der Chiricahua Mountains (Arizona, USA). Hypoponera opacior (Arbeiterin) Eine vorausgegangene Arbeit von Foitzik et al. 2001 zeigt, dass in dieser Art zwei unterschiedliche Sozialsysteme vorkommen. Dabei sind Kolonien mit gefl?gelten Reproduktiven monogyn, unidom d.h. mit einer K?nigin in einem Nest, haben eine unabh?ngige Koloniegr?ndung und sind voraussichtlich ausz?chtend. Im Gegensatz dazu sind Kolonien mit ungefl?gelten Reproduktiven polygyn, polydom d.h. mit mehreren K?niginnen in mehreren Nestern und zeigen eine abh?ngige Koloniegr?ndung mit Nestverpaarung. Im letzteren Fall ist das Paarungsverhalten der M?nnchen sehr ungew?hnlich, denn sie verpaaren sich mit den noch in ihrem Kokon eingeschlossenen Jungk?niginnen ?ber einen Zeitraum von bis zu 40 Stunden. Dies wurde als "mate guarding" (Bewacherverhalten durch eine verl?ngerte Kopulation) beschrieben, da das Sperma bereits in den ersten Minuten der Paarung ?bertragen wird. Fl?gelloses H. opacior M?nnchen w?hrend der Verpaarung mit einer noch im Kokon eingeschlossenen K?nigin Meine Arbeit konzentriert sich vorrangig darauf, die Faktoren aufzudecken, welche den ?bergang in das andere Sozialsystem beeinflussen. Dies geschieht mittels Verhaltensbeobachtungen und Manipulationen ?kologischer Faktoren in Freiland und Labor. Detaillierter werden auch noch das "mate guarding" und das Aggressionsverhalten betrachtet werden. Genetische Untersuchungen werden die Vererbbarkeit der Geschlechtsmorphen, die Koloniestruktur und Inzuchteffekte analysieren. Eine phylogenetische Studie an mehreren Arten der Gattung Hypoponera wird zeigen, ob die verschiedenen alternativen reproduktiven Taktiken einen gemeinsamen Ursprung besitzen oder ob sie konvergent entstanden sind. Dieser Stammbaum wird den ?kologischen Lebensbedingungen der einzelnen Arten gegen?bergestellt werden, um so m?gliche Gemeinsamkeiten aufzuzeigen.

Universität Regensburg - Lehrstuhl Heinze - Biologie Home News Staff Research Teaching Publications Links Markus Rüger Alternative reproductive tactics in the ant genus Hypoponera: In many species sexual selection does not favour one ideal male or female phenotype, but reproductive success is achieved by various tactics. These alternative reproductive tactics can differ in their behaviour, physiology, morphology and in their life histories. Among vertebrates, for example, weaker males are not able to monopolize a harem or to defend a lek. Instead they exhibit a "sneak" strategy. In contrast, males in good condition use open aggression to increase their reproductive success. Also within the ants different strategies are present (see Cremer S., Dr. D'Ettorre P., Schrempf A.). The ant genus Hypoponera shows a great variety of reproductive morphs and tactics, as well in males as in females. Some species show a mating flight of winged sexuals, which is regarded as an ancestral trait, while in others up to two male morphs fight for access to females or show mate guarding. In my PhD-thesis I investigate the alternative reproductive tactics in the species Hypoponera opacior. In this species winged and wingless males and queens occur. Genetical, ecological and behavioural approaches will uncover the proximate reasons for the development of winged and wingless sexuals. Hypoponera opacior is a small ponerine ant. It builts its nests under stones and it catches its prey in the leaf litter and in the soil. The individuals used for the investigations are from the oak-juniper forest in the Chiricahua Mountains (Arizona, U.S.A.). Hypoponera opacior (worker) A former work from Foitzik et al. 2001 show, that two different social systems occur in this species. Colonies with winged reproductives are monogynous, unidomous (i.e. only one queen and one nest per colony), these exhibit independent colony founding and are presumable out breeding. In contrast, colonies with wingless reproductives are polygynous, polydomous (i.e. colonies with more than one queen and nest sites per colony) and show dependent colony foundation with intranidalmating. Wingless males show an unusual male mating behaviour. They mate with the still in the cocoon enclosed females for up to 40 hours. This was described as "mate guarding", because sperm is already transferred during the first minutes of the mating. Apterous male of H. opacior in copula with a still in the cocoon enclosed young queen The main focus of my work is to reveal the factors which trigger the transition into the other social structure. This will be done using behavioural observations and manipulations of ecological factors in the natural habitat and in the laboratory. The conspicuous mate guarding and the aggression behaviour will be investigated in more detail. Genetic analyses will help to clarify the heritability of the different morphs, the colony structure and inbreeding effects. Finally, a phylogenetic study on several species of the genus Hypoponera will show, whether the different alternative reproductive tactics have a common origin or whether they evolved convergence. This phylogenetic tree will be contrasted with the ecological conditions to find possible correspondences.

Universität Regensburg - Lehrstuhl Heinze - Biologie Home Aktuelles Mitarbeiter Forschung Lehre Literatur Links Jesper Stenderup Jesper Stenderup Caribian Freshwater Crabs Supervisor Dr. Christoph Daniel Schubart The main focus for my current project is the phylogenetic relationship of the freshwater crabs from the Greater Antilles (eg. Cuba, Hispaniola, Jamaica) inferred from molecular data with special interest on the Jamaican endemic Sesarmidae. Representatives from all currently described species are available from one or more locations which provides the opportunity to make the phylogenetic reconstruction complete. A rather unique situation in phylogenetics. I will sequence a number of mitochondrial as well as nuclear genes thus giving two independent lines of evidence. This should solve the problems of resolution previous studies on the issues could not. The mitochondrial evidence will be provided form the full length of the 16S as well as some of the 12S gene (already available). The nuclear evidence will come from the ITS complex. This complex consists of two Internal Trancribed Spacers (ITS-1 and ITS-2) divided by the intermediate 5.8S gene and is positioned between the 18S and 28S genes. The two ITS? are very variable while the rRNA?s are quite conserved. This should provide Linksrmation on several levels and hopefully help resolve the problem at hand. The data will be analysed using currently available methods, such as parsimony, likelihood and Bayesian inference, and implementing the best models of evolution. Since intragenomic variation in ITS1 and ITS2 is known to exist in crayfish for example, and we have reason to believe that this is also the case with the Sesarmidae, I am cloning the ITS region of five populations from each of two species (S. windsor and S. meridies) in order to determine whether the variation is greater within the species/populations than between them. This will be done at Dr. Keith Crandall?s lab at Brigham Young University in Provo, Utah during February and March of 2004. Since the ITS fragments are so variable, and also found in more then one copy, cloning of this could provide the necessary Linksrmation help in order to make us understand the apparently extremely fast speciation events of the Jamaican Sesarmidae. Based on these results, new species or subspecies will be described. Click here for pdf of C.V.

This complex consists of two Internal Trancribed Spacers (ITS-1 and ITS-2) divided by the intermediate 5.8S gene and is positioned between the 18S and 28S genes. The two ITS? are very variable while the rRNA?s are quite conserved. This should provide Linksrmation on several levels and hopefully help resolve the problem at hand. The data will be analysed using currently available methods, such as parsimony, likelihood and Bayesian inference, and implementing the best models of evolution. Since intragenomic variation in ITS1 and ITS2 is known to exist in crayfish for example, and we have reason to believe that this is also the case with the Sesarmidae, I am cloning the ITS region of five populations from each of two species (S. windsor and S. meridies) in order to determine whether the variation is greater within the species/populations than between them. This will be done at Dr. Keith Crandall?s lab at Brigham Young University in Provo, Utah during February and March of 2004. Since the ITS fragments are so variable, and also found in more then one copy, cloning of this could provide the necessary Linksrmation help in order to make us understand the apparently extremely fast speciation events of the Jamaican Sesarmidae. Based on these results, new species or subspecies will be described. Click here for pdf of C.V.

Universität Regensburg - Lehrstuhl Heinze - Biologie Home News Staff Research Teaching Publications Links Michaela Strätz Research:Colony founding by the ant Leptothorax nylanderi In different populations of Leptothorax nylanderi (Myrmicinae), a monogynous and monandrous ant species, possible colony founding and distribution strategie will be investigated. Because of the relatedness assymetry of the workers we expect a sex ratio of 3:1 in the whole population when workers are the controlling party (queen worker conflict). In this respect it is interesting which parameters affect the sex ratio. This study aims to identify causes for a possible deviation of the expectation and which sex ratios do appear in single colonies. Another question is how the workers can influence the sex ratio and react against the queen. Strong competition for nest sites in L. nylanderi leads to colony fusion, colony takeover and usurpation of virgin queens. That?s why the genetic structure and following also the relatedness in colonies may change and eventually also does the sex ratio. Two W?rzburger populations were mapped exactly and their genetic composition I am examining with microsatellites to see wether there appears heterogenity in the single societies. From the results we may suggest if neighboured colonies fuse or if societies split (polydomy). Through a comparison with a previous study of one of the populations, sampled at a time when the density was three times higher, we may find out how the ecological parameter density can influence population structure and colony composition. The question is wether ?intraspecific parasitism? occurs. In behavioural experimentes we try to get an overview how already existing societies are taken over by alien queens. There may be morphological differences between the queens. Additionally, we will compare the primary sex ratio (ratio of female to male eggs) achieved by karyotyping eggs with the secondary sex ratio (ratio of female to male adults) in the populations. In furhter behavioural experiments in the lab we try to find out how queen or worker influence these ratios.

Prof. Dr. Jürgen Heinze - Evolution, Verhalten und Genetik

Prof. Dr. Jürgen Heinze - Evolution, Verhalten und Genetik Universität Regensburg > Fakultäten> Biologie und Vkl > Einrichtungen > Zoologie > Prof. Dr. Jürgen Heinze > Research > Ants Home Links Staff Research Teaching Publications Research - Ants Our group studies different problems in evolutionary biology, including the following aspects: Reproductive Conflict and Sociogenetics Population Genetics Alternative Reproductive Strategies Ecophysiology of Boreal Ant Species Communication and Colony Odour Reproductive Conflict and Sociogenetics When animals live together in groups, conflicts arise concerning the access to limited resources and the partitioning of reproduction. In many species, including primates and carnivors, these conflicts may lead to the formation of dominance hierarchies, in which reproductive success depends on the social status of an individual. In contrast, all members in the groups of other species, e.g., acorn woodpeckers, appear to have the same "rights". Models based on Hamilton's kin selection theory and game theory make predictions about how group structure is affected by ecological and genetic parameters. We attempt to test these predictions by investigating reproductive conflict in insect societies, especially the ant genera Pachycondyla and Leptothorax. In addition we investigate the proximate and ultimate causes of conflict between queens and workers and within the two female castes, applying methods from genetics, population genetics, ecology, chemical ecology and ethology. We use a wide range of genetic, population genetic, ecological and ethological methods, e.g. microsatellite analysis, allozyme gel-electrophoresis, computer- and video- based longterm observations, F-statistic ... dominance hierarchies kin selection structure of ant societies methods Population Genetics To understand the ultimate causes of reproductive conflict in animal groups it is necessary to determine population structure. Using genetic markers we could for example clarify how the populations of several Central European ant species are organized, i.e. whether they are substructured and to what extent inbreeding or Wahlund effects do occur. From the discrepancy between genetic and sociometric observations in some species we could demonstrate for the first time the common occurrence of intraspecific parasitism and colony fission in ants. Genetic structure of ant populations intraspecific parasitism Alternative Reproductive Strategies Individuals of many species use different strategies to maximize their fitness, i.e. the number of their offspring. In addition to the typical winged queens, in some ant species wingless queens occur, which use different tactics for dispersal and reproduction. The determination of the proximate causes of queen polymorphism and its consequences on the genetic structure of colonies and populations shed light on the understanding of alternative reproductive strategies in social insects. Another, on first view similar polymorphism is known from males in the ant genus Cardiocondyla. Here the two morphs show fascinating differences in behavior, physiology and reproduction. The winged males behave peacefully, similar to the typical male ants, and presumably mate outside of their maternal colonies with alien queens. Sperm production has stopped by the time they leave the maternal nest. In contrast, wingless males aggressively attack their rivals and attempt to monopolize matings with newly emerging queens in their own nest. Spermatogenesis continues for the whole lifespan of wingless males. Using genetic and histological investigations we try to determine what proximately causes this polymorphism and how it evolved. We also investigate the systematics of ants with a completely different reproductive strategy: the social parasites and slave makers. queen polymorphism fighting males Evolution of social parasitism for more details see Alexandra Schrempf Ecophysiology of Boreal Ant Species Even though most ant species are distributed in tropical areas, some can be found in alpine and boreal habitats near the tree-line. In collaboration with Russian researchers we study how these species are adapted to cold climate. adaptions of boreal ant species to cold climate Communication and Colony Odour We use gas chromatography and mass spectrometry to analyse the composition of the cuticular hydrocarbon blends and gland contents in ant species. Aim of these studies is to understand the mechanisms of chemical communication and the Linksrmation processing of biologically active compound. We investigate the chemical strategy for colony usurpation in socially parasitic ants, the basis of rank recognition in dominance hierarchies and the role of fertility signals. We work in cooperation with the group of Prof. B. König, Inst. of Organic Chemistry. colony odour rank recognition Impressum

Universität Regensburg - Evolution, Verhalten und Genetik Universität Regensburg > Fakultäten > Biologie und Vkl > Einrichtungen > Zoologie > LS Heinze > Mitarbeiter > Christoph Schubart > CV Links Staff Research Teaching Publications Dr. Christoph Schubart Recent Publications Scientific Interests Curriculum vitae: 1986-1992. Study of Biology at the Albert-Ludwigs-Universität, Freiburg (Germany), including one year as a visiting graduate student at the University of Washington, Seattle (Fulbright scholar) (1989-1990) and six months as a research assistant of Dr. Richard Strathmann at the Friday Harbor Marine Laboratories (USA) (1992). Diplom thesis: "Recruitment of Balanus glandula into empty adult barnacle tests and its ecological implications at the San Juan Islands, WA" (advisor: Dr. K. Peschke, external advisor: Dr. Richard R. Strathmann). 1993-1997. Doctoral student at the University of Bielefeld (Germany) with support of DAAD and DFG. Field work on mangrove and land-dwelling crabs in the Caribbean, mainly Jamaica and Panama; laboratory work at the Institute of Molecular Evolutionary Genetics of the Pennsylvania State University (USA) with Dr. Blair Hedges. Ph.D. thesis: "Ecophysiology, morphology, and molecular phylogeny of the American Sesarma (Brachyura: Grapsidae), with emphasis on the Jamaican endemic species" (advisor: Dr. R. Diesel, external advisor: Dr. S. Blair Hedges). 1997-1999. Post-doc at the University of Louisiana, Lafayette (USA). Research associate at the Laboratory of Crustacean Research under Dr. Darryl Felder, funded by the U.S. Department of Energy. Field of investigation: cryptic endemism among decapod Crustacea of the Gulf of Mexico. Field studies in Carolina, Georgia, Florida, Gulf of Mexico, Yucatán and Gulf of California (USA and Mexico). Return for continuing studies from August to November 2000. 1999-2000. Post-doc at the National University of Singapore. Research fellowship under Dr. Peter K. L. Ng and in association with the Raffles Museum. Field work in Singapore, Malaysia, Thailand, Indonesia, and Taiwan. Assessment of marine coastal and freshwater crustaceans of Southeast Asia with description of several new species and genera. Collection of material to be used for molecular phylogenetics and description of terrestrial radiations within tropical Brachyura. Since 2000. Assistant Professor at the Institute of Zoology, University of Regensburg (Lehrstuhl Biologie I, Prof. Jürgen Heinze). Field work in the Caribbean, Mediterranean, and Southeast Asia. Molecular phylogeny of Thoracotremata (Grapsoidea, Ocypodoidea, Pinnotheroidea ...), Xanthoidea, Portunoidea and freshwater Decapoda; radiations of non-marine crustaceans in tropical habitats (DFG Schu 1460/3, Schu 1460/6); endemism in the Mediterranean Sea and Gulf of Mexico; crustacean radiations on the Antarctic Shelf (ANR, DFG Schu 1460/8). DAAD exchange projects with Spain, Italy,Bulgaria, Brazil, Chile, and Hongkong. Advisor of Ph.D. students (finished: Silke Reuschel, Sebastian Klaus, Tobias Santl; current: Peter Koller, Nicole Rivera, Alireza Keikhosravi, Nicolas Thiercelin, Shobhit Agrawal, Temim Deli), Diplom, Master and Bachelor students. Impressum

Sc. Alexander Schiller, M. Sc. Wissenschaftlicher Mitarbeiter Zur Person Alexander Schiller, geboren 1989 in Regensburg, absolvierte von Oktober 2008 bis September 2011 den Studiengang Bachelor of Science Mathematik mit Nebenfach Volkswirtschaftslehre an der Universität Regensburg. Dabei legte er seinen Schwerpunkt auf den Bereich der Arithmetischen Geometrie. Währenddessen arbeitete er als studentische Hilfskraft an der Fakultät für Mathematik. In seiner Bachelorarbeit befasste er sich mit formalen Gruppen und lokaler Klassenkörpertheorie.Von Oktober 2011 bis Januar 2014 studierte Alexander Schiller an der Universität Regensburg den Studiengang Master of Science Mathematik. Er vertiefte sich dabei weiterhin im Bereich der Arithmetischen Geometrie und entschied sich für das Nebenfach Wirtschaftsinformatik. In seiner Masterarbeit untersuchte er Positivitätseigenschaften der Deligne-Paarung.Im September 2012 begann Alexander Schiller mit seiner Arbeit als nWHK am Lehrstuhl für Wirtschaftsinformatik II der Universität Regensburg. Seit Februar 2014 ist er als wissenschaftlicher Mitarbeiter am Lehrstuhl tätig. Webmaster · Intern

Raum VG 3.37 Sprechstunde nach Vereinbahrung Team Prof. Dr. Bernd Heinrich Prof. Dr. Bernd Heinrich Lehrstuhlinhaber Wirtschaftsinformatik II Der Lehrstuhl für Wirtschaftsinformatik II entwickelt auf wissenschaftlicher Grundlage Konzepte, Methoden und Softwareprototypen, die zu einer fundierten, gestaltungsorientierten Lösung für praxisrelevante Problemstellungen - vor allem von Finanzdienstleistern - führen sollen. So ergibt sich ein idealer Brückenschlag zwischen Grundlagenforschung und anwendungsorientierter Forschung in Kooperation mit Praxispartnern. Dies ermöglicht es, den Studierenden fundierte Kenntnisse aber vor allem auch methodische Fähigkeiten sowie den jeweiligen praktischen Einsatz bei Unternehmen anschaulich zu vermitteln. Forschungsthemen Die Forschungsthemen umfassen sowohl theoretische als auch praxisrelevante Fragestellungen der Wirtschaftsinformatik insbesondere mit Bezug zu Finanzdienstleistern: Prozessmanagement, -simulation und -planung Flexibilisierung von Prozessen mit Hilfe semantischer Web Services Planung und Entwicklung von Location-based Services und Applikationen auf mobilen Endgeräten Messung der Daten-/Informationsqualität und ökonomische Planung von Datenqualitätsmaßnahmen Diffusion von Plattformen im Bereich Online Social Networks und Social Media Ausbildungsziele Den Studierenden wird eine methodisch fundierte und zugleich praxisrelevante Bildung angeboten, wobei die Lehrinhalte mit den oben genannten Forschungsthemen stark korrespondieren. Die vermittelten Methoden und Kenntnisse zielen dabei nicht nur auf eine berufliche Tätigkeit bei Finanzdienstleistern auf allen Hierarchieebenen ab. Vielmehr ist eine Vielzahl der Konzepte gleichermaßen für andere Dienstleistungsbranchen sehr relevant. Damit wird eine ideale Basis für Ihre spätere Karriere in der Praxis (bspw. auch in einem Beratungsunternehmen) oder für weiterführende Masterstudiengänge gelegt. Sie erhalten auf diese Weise ein einschlägiges und erfolgversprechendes Profil, welches Sie für eine konzeptionelle Tätigkeit vom fachlichen Entwurf bis zur Realisierung auszeichnet. Zur Person Bernd Heinrich, geboren 1972, studierte von 1994-1999 Wirtschaftsinformatik an der Universität Regensburg mit den Schwerpunkten Information Engineering, Bankinformatik und Operations Research. Von 1999 bis 2002 promovierte er an der Universität St. Gallen/Schweiz am Lehrstuhl von Prof. Dr. Robert Winter im Bereich Informationssystemarchitekturen und Kundenbeziehungsmanagement. Von 2002 bis 2008 war Bernd Heinrich wissenschaftlicher Assistent am Lehrstuhl von Prof. Dr. Hans Ulrich Buhl. Hier akquirierte und leitete er federführend unter anderem das DFG-Forschungsprojekt "Modellierung, Selbstkomposition und Selbstkonfiguration von Referenzprozessen auf Basis semantischer Konzepte (SEMPRO)". Auch an der erfolgreichen Akquisition des DFG-Nachfolgeprojekts SEMPRO2 war er maßgeblich beteiligt. Daneben führte er eine Reihe von anwendungsorientierten Forschungsprojekten bei der Siemens AG, der Fujitsu Siemens Computers GmbH, der HypoVereinsbank AG sowie der Allianz AG durch. Im Jahre 2007 habilitierte er sich zum Thema ?Gestaltung von Informationssystemarchitekturen: Optimierungsmodelle und Algorithmen für die Planung und Bewertung von Datenqualitätsmaßnahmen, Prozessrestrukturierungen und Kommunikationsstandards?. Für seine Habilitationsschrift erhielt er 2007 den Förderpreis der Bayerischen Landesbank sowie den Wissenschaftspreis der UPM Kymmene GmbH. Im Jahr 2009 erhielt er für sein herausragendes Engagement und seine besonderen Leistungen zur Profilbildung der Wirtschaftswissenschaftlichen Fakultät Augsburg den Wissenschaftspreis der Kurt und Felicitas Viermetz Stiftung. Daneben konnte Bernd Heinrich unter anderem erfolgreich das FWF-Forschungsprojekt "Automatisierte Planung von Prozessmodellen" einwerben, das noch bis 2016 laufen wird. Im Oktober 2011 übernahm er den Lehrstuhl für Wirtschaftsinformatik II, insbesondere Bankinformatik an der Universität Regensburg. Bernd Heinrich ist als Gutachter und Editor internationaler Fachkonferenzen sowie wissenschaftlicher Zeitschriften tätig. Er ist Autor zahlreicher Beiträge in Büchern und Fachzeitschriften wie beispielsweise Zeitschrift für Betriebswirtschaft (ZfB), Die Betriebswirtschaft (DBW), Die Wirtschaftsinformatik, Electronic Markets (EM), Information Systems and E-Business Management (ISeB), Business Process Management Journal (BPMJ), Journal of Information Science (JIS), Academy of Marketing Science Review oder ACM Journal of Data and Information Quality (JDIQ). Daneben hat er die Ergebnisse vieler Arbeiten auf wissenschaftlichen Konferenzen (bspw. International Conference on Information Systems (ICIS), European Conference on Information Systems (ECIS), International Conference on Information Quality (ICIQ) oder Internationale Tagung Wirtschaftsinformatik) präsentiert. Seine Forschungsinteressen liegen in den Themengebieten Daten- und Informationsqualität bspw. im Kundenbeziehungsmanagement von Banken, Prozessplanung und -simulation bei Finanzdienstleistern, Diffusion von Kommunikationsstandards und Plattformen insbesondere im Bereich Online Social Networks, Serviceorientierte Architekturen, Flexibilisierung von Prozessen bei Banken mit Hilfe von Web Services sowie Planung und Entwicklung von Location-based Services und Applikationen auf mobilen Endgeräten. Webmaster · Intern
